title: Simulating the Gold in the Ground
text: Welcome GoldinGroundOz package! vignette walks package built aims demonstrate. begin, important reminder: data package simulated. generated resemble general patterns real-world Australian housing income trends â€” actual figures, real economic inference drawn .

title: Simulating the Gold in the Ground
text: story behind name Gold Ground simple â€” Australiaâ€™s housing market long fascinating subject, property prices often growing faster household income.

title: Simulating the Gold in the Ground
text: explore idea visually, created two small datasets: housepr_income: showing detached house prices household disposable income 1990â€“2023, simulated move realistic long-term pattern. Variables housepr_income dataset capital_gain: representing average capital gain rate changes 1986â€“2020, policy-phase split (â€œâ€ vs.Â â€œâ€ 50% capital gains discount). Variables capital_gain dataset , artificial, designed mimic shape real-world trends.

title: Simulating the Gold in the Ground
code: library(GoldinGroundOz) data("housepr_income") data("capital_gain")  head(housepr_income) #>   year    income house_price #> 1 1990  93.79697    62.51829 #> 2 1991 105.44149   103.79164 #> 3 1992 113.07616    76.21912 #> 4 1993 113.57105   128.17242 #> 5 1994 109.85777   129.47045 #> 6 1995 120.96476   134.05761 head(capital_gain) #>      year                             phase    value #> 1 1986-87 Before 50% capital gains discount 5887.859 #> 2 1987-88 Before 50% capital gains discount 2991.685 #> 3 1988-89 Before 50% capital gains discount 3131.357 #> 4 1989-90 Before 50% capital gains discount 3487.970 #> 5 1990-91 Before 50% capital gains discount 2885.084 #> 6 1991-92 Before 50% capital gains discount 5223.711

what: Exploring the Relationship Between Household Disposable Income, Detached House Prices, and Capital Gain Rate Changes in Australia
title: Exploring the Relationship Between Household Disposable Income, Detached House Prices, and Capital Gain Rate Changes in Australia
text: GoldinGroundOz small exploratory R package demonstrates long-term relationship Australiaâ€™s detached house prices, household disposable income, average capital gain rate changes. provides two simulated datasets illustrative examples explore one hidden forces behind Australiaâ€™s surging housing prices â€” shifting patterns capital gain rates, â€œgold lies beneath ground.â€

title: Exploring the Relationship Between Household Disposable Income, Detached House Prices, and Capital Gain Rate Changes in Australia
text: See full documentation Shiny app demo pkgdown website ðŸ‘‡ ðŸ”— GoldinGroundOz pkgdown site

title: Exploring the Relationship Between Household Disposable Income, Detached House Prices, and Capital Gain Rate Changes in Australia
text: simple example exploring included datasets:
code: library(GoldinGroundOz)  # Load the datasets data("housepr_income") data("capital_gain")  # Quick overview head(housepr_income) #>   year    income house_price #> 1 1990  93.79697    62.51829 #> 2 1991 105.44149   103.79164 #> 3 1992 113.07616    76.21912 #> 4 1993 113.57105   128.17242 #> 5 1994 109.85777   129.47045 #> 6 1995 120.96476   134.05761 head(capital_gain) #>      year                             phase    value #> 1 1986-87 Before 50% capital gains discount 5887.859 #> 2 1987-88 Before 50% capital gains discount 2991.685 #> 3 1988-89 Before 50% capital gains discount 3131.357 #> 4 1989-90 Before 50% capital gains discount 3487.970 #> 5 1990-91 Before 50% capital gains discount 2885.084 #> 6 1991-92 Before 50% capital gains discount 5223.711  # Plot house prices vs disposable income plot( housepr_income$year, housepr_income$house_price, type = "l", col = "gold", lwd = 2, ylab = "Index (1989â€“90 = 100)", xlab = "Year" ) lines(housepr_income$year, housepr_income$income, col = "pink", lwd = 2) legend("topleft", legend = c("House Prices", "Disposable Income"), col = c("gold", "pink"), lwd = 2)

title: Simulated Average Capital Gain Rate Change â€” capital_gain
Simulated Average Capital Gain Rate Change â€” capital_gain
text: data frame 34 rows 3 variables: year character, formatted "YYYY-YY" phase character, indicating policy period value numeric, simulated capital gain rate (basis points)

title: Simulated Average Capital Gain Rate Change â€” capital_gain
text: Simulated data inspired real Australian financial trends â€” serious analysis recommended. Patterns designed mimic real-world shapes, numbers fully synthetic.
